SODIUM FLUORIDE

  • Indications and doses
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Prescribing and dispensing
  • Profession specific information
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Prophylaxis of dental caries for water content less than 300micrograms/litre (0.3 parts per million) of fluoride ion,

By mouth using tablets

  • For adults
    1 mg daily, doses expressed as fluoride ion (F-).
  • For children 6 months–2 years
    250 micrograms daily, doses expressed as fluoride ion (F-).
  • For children 3–5 years
    500 micrograms daily, doses expressed as fluoride ion (F-).
  • For children 6–17 years
    1 mg daily, doses expressed as fluoride ion (F-).

Prophylaxis of dental caries for water content between 300 and 700micrograms/litre (0.3–0.7 parts per million) of fluoride ion,

By mouth using tablets

  • For adults
    500 micrograms daily, doses expressed as fluoride ion (F-).
  • For children 3–5 years
    250 micrograms daily, doses expressed as fluoride ion (F-).
  • For children 6–17 years
    500 micrograms daily, doses expressed as fluoride ion (F-).

Prophylaxis of dental caries for water content above 700micrograms/litre (0.7 parts per million) of fluoride ion,

  • For adults
    Supplements not advised.
  • For children 6 months–17 years
    Supplements not advised.

Prophylaxis of dental carries for individuals who are caries prone or medically compromised,

By mouth using mouthwash

  • For adults
    Rinse or gargle 10 mL daily.
  • For children 6–17 years
    Rinse or gargle 10 mL daily.

Dose equivalence and conversion

Sodium fluoride 2.2 mg provides approx. 1 mg fluoride ion.

These doses reflect the recommendations of the British Dental Association, the British Society of Paediatric Dentistry and the British Association for the Study of Community Dentistry (Br Dent J 1997; 182: 6–7).

Contra indications

  • Not for areas where drinking water is fluoridated

Known side effects

General side effects

uncommon: Occasional white flecks on teeth with recommended doses,

rare: Yellowish-brown discoloration if recommended doses are exceeded,

Directions for administration

With oral use

Tablets should be sucked or dissolved in the mouth and taken preferably in the evening.

With oral (topical) use

For mouthwash, rinse mouth for 1 minute and then spit out.

Advice for patients and carers

With oral (topical) use

Mouthwash

Avoid eating, drinking, or rinsing mouth for 15 minutes after use.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Flavours of oral tablet formulations may include orange.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

Tablets may be prescribed as Sodium Fluoride Tablets.

Oral drops may be prescribed as Sodium Fluoride Oral Drops.

Mouthwashes may be prescribed as Sodium Fluoride Mouthwash 0.05% or Sodium Fluoride Mouthwash 2%.

Prepared medicinal forms of SODIUM FLUORIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral solution, capsule,
Tablet
Chewable tablet
Oral drops
Paste
Mouthwash
